pullRequest.body:
We add a new file with API for an `IsRkFinite` predicate on sets in a matroid, stating that a set has a finite basis. This property is closed under subsets and finite unions. 

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR

Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

Deletions:

- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

</details>

`+ isRkFinite_iff_exists_basis'`
`+ isRkFinite_insert_iff`
`+ isRkFinite_inter_ground_iff`
`+ isRkFinite_of_finite`

`+ isRkFinite_singleton`
`+++ _`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Can you add a more descriptive PR description?

bors d+

:v: apnelson1 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks, @b-mehta 

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13306781177/job/37159474438)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13306781177/job/37159474155)

```suggestion
/-- a `RankFin` set in `M` is one whose bases are all finite. -/
def RankFin (M : Matroid ) (X : Set ) : Prop := (M  X).RankFinite
```
seems more appropriate, given how rank is now written!
No - the new convention is that `rank`/`Rank` is referring to the rank of the whole matroid, while `rk`/`Rk` is the rank of a set within the matroid.
Ah okay, I missed that, thanks. Would `RkFinite` be better here then? The atom `Fin` usually refers to the type `Fin` (and isn't comparable to `Fintype` since that's not written as `FinType`)

Note that this is another exception to the `Is`-naming convention (eg discussed here https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Naming.20conventions.20for.20.60Prop.60-valued.20defs.20and.20classes). I find some of the matroid lemmas confusing to read because of this - particularly the ones involving `Basis` and `Circuit`: `Basis` in other parts of mathlib is the data of a basis, whereas here it's the proposition that a set is a basis! Please consider renaming the matroid ones sooner rather than later, to avoid it being too time-consuming to adjust to.
I do take this point. Do you think it is ok to draw the line at adjectives, though? `IsIndep` makes my fingers unhappy.
Yeah, I think that's fine

It seems cleaner to me to give these two first, and have the others as aliases. That way, it's also clearer from reading the file which are the ones with mathematical meaning, and which are present just for nice dot notation.

```suggestion
lemma rkFin_singleton {M : Matroid } {e : } : M.RkFin {e} :=
```
A lemma like this (and the below) is usually more commonly written with implicit arguments. (I can also see an argument for having M explicit but not e, for dot notation). That way, when you're using this with dot notation, you can write the clean `rkFin_singleton.exists_finite_basis'`, for example, rather than `(rkFin_singleton e).exists_finite_basis'`.
I'm not sure this name is the right one, but I don't have a better idea off the top of my head.

```suggestion
  exact fun h  h.subset <| M.inter_ground_subset_closure X, fun h  h.closure
```
looks like this should work?
It doesn't, because of the rewrite in the first line.
I'd say a lemma like this doesn't need to exist, since it's just `mt`  with `RkFin.subset` and `hXY`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Matroid/Rank): finite-rank sets in matroids
